review.review_text: Went here for an afternoon snack. We got one frangipane croissant, a veggie quiche, 2 coffees and a matcha. The croissant was very sweet with a nice flavour. The Quiche was very cheesy and tasty, but needed some salt or sauce. The drinks were fine too.

Couldn't say that I've ever stood in line for >30mins for a coffee/bite to eat but when it's got a 4.9 rating and has a line wrapped around the block, you know it's going to be worth the wait. 

Almond croissant + coffee was divine. Crispy, buttery, decadent but divine. This place is worth the hype and the wait. Don't take my word for it, try it for yourself.

Morning bun cannot be given a miss, coated in sugar crystals every bite is a delight. It’s a pretty popular cafe that’s mostly crowded n had us share our table. If you wanna grab their morning buns, plan to be here early before they run out of it.

A colleague recommended this place, and while the queues out the door made me wonder if the wait was really worth it, the amazing morning buns removed all doubt. I'll definitely be returning next time I'm in San Francisco!

Perfect french patisserie at the outskirt of SF. If you are looking to tour around the painted ladies then go early and head to Tartine for breakfast. Love the quiche, bread pudding, croissant (big enough for two) and morning bun (must have). If you love lemon pie, theirs are perfect. And don’t be surprised to see many left with box of patisserie or cakes since early in the morning

Artisan bakery shop in San Fransisco, there is no signage of it but you could easily find this place by looking at line of people at the front. The place is tiny, they sell variety of danish and croissant freshly made, cake and tart. I try the lemon tart $7.25 which has nice tart shell and tangy, pain au chocolate with valrhona choco filling $5 (varlrhona has bitter and sour aftertaste) which blend nicely with the crunchiness of the pastry, ham quiche $6.25 (the ham so salty), currant scone $3.75 with freestyle shape can be taste with butter and additional charge for jam, and hot chocolate $3.5. Perfect for breakfast or brunch.
Banana cream tart is bomb. The chocolate, caramel and whipped cream are perfect together with the flaky crust. Definitely a must get at tartine.

Exactly as it should be.  A true bakery.  I pretended to buy something for all 4 of us but ended up on splitting it all with daughter.  We had an extended breakfast in nearby Dolores Park.  Chocolatine, tarte citron, quiche, morning bun, croissant, espresso macchiato...all exactly as they should taste.  Line predictably snaked out like a big number 5 starting from the smartly placed coffee station, past the cash, along the display cases, past the vitrine, concluding this perfect score as a 180 through the door and 15 feet down the sidewalk.  Worth the wait...even if I did not see mille-feuille that morning.

I have a true affection for viennoiserie so it was a no-brainer to visit the James Beard Award winning Tartine Bakery on my recent trip to San Francisco. I went around 3 pm on a Monday so the line-up was reasonable and, in fact, appreciated as I had to contemplate what I wanted from the showcase of pastries. I chose the Morning Bun, Pain au Chocolat, and Gougere. The Morning Bun was dusted with cinnamon sugar and had hints of candied orange zest. While the flavours were good, the texture was drier than I had anticipated. I only wished that the interior was softer and fluffier. The pastry of the Pain au Chocolat wasn't as light and flaky as the one from Mr. Holmes Bakehouse, and the chocolate filling wasn't as tasty as others that I've had. I did, however, enjoy the Gougere. It was unique - a savoury egg dough with Gruyere, thyme, and black pepper. Of the three, I would certainly order the Gougere again. 
Tartine wasn't a disappointment by any means but I had greater expectations for this San Francisco landmark.

This place is an institution so I really should have tried more on this trip. But I seriously didn't have any stomach space left. I tried their morning bun a few years ago, so had really hoped to try a few more things this time. But alas, all I could manage was this salted chocolate brownie which was seriously tasty. Very chocolatey with the requisite chewy texture. Excellent.

Keske yeri daha merkezi olsaydi da hergun gidebilseydik dedigimiz bir mekan. Hic bu kadar lezzetli bir croissant yememistim. Morning bun ve croque monsieur de tavsiye ederim. Lemon cream tart ise ayri bir efsaneydi.

Had a Lemon Meringue cake and Brioche Butter Pudding with caramelized banana topping. The meringue cake wasn't good and was too sweet, maybe cuz I'm not a fan of lemon cake. My cousin wanted that. But the Brioche butter pudding was out of this world! Too good to be true!! Definitely will come back for it and to try some more pastries

[full San Francisco review on my blog] Out of the city, on a residential type street, mid morning on a grey and drizzly Wednesday, there was a line out the door and you couldn’t move inside. It’s worse on weekends. Great coffee and plenty of treats on offer. Below is a pain au chocolat (flaky and light), their famed morning bun (we loved it, that was the favourite), the frangipane tart (take it or leave it) and the chocolate tea cake (good distinct chocolate flavour but not too heavy). To go to have later we bought a lemon tart (tangy, I thought it was decent but not great, though the Marito loved it) and the chocolate hazelnut tart which was disappointing, not hazelnutty enough. I didn’t get to try the sourdough bread they are particularly famous for – they don’t sell bread in the mornings. It’s a bit of a trade-off – go in the mornings, miss the bread. Go in the afternoons, miss the morning bun and other treats.
Worth waiting the long line in front of it! We couldn't able to make it to the breakfast but the desserts were amazing! Definitely Try the Almond Cake :)

Worth It!. I didn't expect transportation to be over $21, but it was worth every penny to try the seemingly magical textures of the morning bun and croissant. I'll be back to try more before I leave tomorrow.

JAMBON ROYALE. I'd been looking forward to Tartine since, basically, forever, and I did the wrong thing and ordered the wrong sandwich. Humboldt Fog (still good, btw, but not THA BEST). If you want to order the best sandwich, like my brilliant mother did, order the Jambon Royale. You will never regret it. And get a croissant, too. You'll plan to eat it for breakfast, or for an afternoon snack, but you won't. You'll eat it right there. And you'll never regret that either. Only negative thing I have to say is that I didn't like the bread pudding; others did, though, so I guess it was just too eggy for me.

-----09 Jul, 2014-----
Croissant. More butter couldn't have possibly been packed into the thing. And I couldn't have been happier.

-----09 Jul, 2014-----
Jambon Royale & Gruyère. The best sandwich I've ever had, probably. I just don't have many more words than that.

Stick with the pastries. The pressed sandwich was greasy, the cheese only partially melted (I had the Spanish cheese with quince jam), the crust on the bread tough enough to crack a tooth. The rude and snippy blonde at the counter was enough to keep me from returning, but the real issue was lack of cleanliness. The water glasses and pitchers of water sit five inches above the bins of piled, dirty dishes and crockery, on an open Metro shelf, so mess from the dishes tossed into those bins can splash on the upside-down glasses. (The water is self-serve and the dirty dishes are bused by customers.) By 1:00 the dish bins were a thoroughly disgusting jumble of filth. The two tarts I took home (frangipani and hazelnut-chocolate) were quite good, but I will never eat at the cafe again.
Disappointing given the hype. Only tried the Banana cream pie. It was tasty enough but a pretty average pie. The pastry was hard and the filling was very simple caramel bananas and too much cream.
Their morning bun is good soft buttery flakes with center embedded with lots of cinnamon. It's a two thumbs up here very hipster like so if you come for the eats you'll be okay.
Delicious Treats. Everything is yummy and lovely made... there's a line for a reason!

A San Francisco Institution. Every time I visit back, Tartine is first on the list. I've tried just about everything they have to offer and have never been disappointed.
About half the time there's a line out the door, but it usually moves quickly and there isn't too much trouble finding a seat.
Excellent! Tartine was the starting point for our walking tour and I couldn't think of a better way to start the day!
Best croissants in the SF Bay Area. Great breads also. There is one BIG downside. This place is insanely crowded. Line forms before opening every weekend

Delicious!. My friends and I went here for post-pilates snacks and decided to share an assortment of goodies to recoop some of our calories. 

If anyone ever has a chance to go to this bakery, regardless of time of day, have a slice of the Passion Fruit Lime Bavarian. I am a huge passion fruit fan, and this rendition has been delighting my memory since I tasted it three years ago.

Oh, and the other goodies were delicious also!
The croissants are perfect. I had the lemon cream tart and leaped for joy. Very yummy!

Holy cow is this place ever worth the wait!. I was urged to get to Tartine early – so we were in line around 9:30 am. Even so, the line poured onto the sidewalk and took a good 15 minutes to get through. Was it worth the wait?? Um. HELL to the mf YES. My friends and I ordered americanos, berry bread pudding, meringue cake, chocolate pudding and a ham croissant. The croissant was about as big as my head and stuffed to bursting with perfectly prepared ham and cheese. The bread pudding was soft but not soggy and the berries were not neglected – both of the sweets were just sweet enough, and thick, rich and creamy. I would easily wait 30 minutes in this line to try a new breakfast treat. Tartine will cure what ails you!

O.M.G.. Waited in a long line to try a Ham and Cheese pressed sandwich...was well worth the wait and I'll do it again!! We were too late int eh day for all the bakery goodies, so next time I will go early. This place is Heaven on Earth.

Heaven!!!. It took a little searching but I finally found it close to our hotel and it was well worth it! 
This is a place to leave your diet at the door and indulge because you will likely not find a bakery this good anytime soon!

BEST chocolate croissant EVER!. I went to this bakery as soon as i got off the plane! Iced coffee, chocolate croissant, and chocolate eclair. SOOOO delicious! You can smell this place from across the street! The croissant was crunchy and it didn't have too much chocolate which i liked. The eclair was surprisingly light. Custard was not too sweet either. Ice coffee was meh. It went well all together. Will visit again the next time i'm in SF!

BREAK YOUR DIET. If there was one time to break your diet and indulge yourself... This is IT! came to san fran for a week and was told this is a MUST VISIT... dont be detterred by the wait... its worth it!

Worth the Hype. I went twice on my trip to SF! 

Once was not enough. Had the chocolate croissant, mocha one time and a quiche and croque monsieur with a friend another time.

It is outstanding. Yes there is a long line, but that should reflect on how good this place is, and the line does go fast. 

Some may complain about the service - i personally think its perfectly fine considering the number of patrons waiting to chomp on their gastronomic delights!

I would go again and again.
The Opera Cake is to die for!!!
Bread Pudding.. That is all I have to say on the subject of tartine. If you get the chance to go there, get the bread pudding. Thank me later.

How can you not love it?!?. It's amazing, best pain au chocolat I've had in a long while. I got my food to go (it's just a short walk to Dolores park, which has a beautiful view). It was rather crowded, however, it does seem like a nice place to sit and enjoy, IF you can find a table. I walked by many times when I was in town, the line always went out the door. It's totally worth it!

Too popular for its own good. Great place! Excellent croissants, as everyone says. But during three years of living in San Francisco, I only stopped here occasionally. Parking is impossible (I always kvetch about parking in S.F.) so we'd usually have to do a jump-out while the other person orbited around the block in the car. Then there were the lines, and the sold-outness. In a town with as many good bakeries as San Francisco, I'm not going to bend myself into a palmier for Tartine, excellent though it might be.

Drawn by the allure of Tartine bread, we were too early to stand in line for a loaf. So we opted for lunch instead, and settled for lunch instead. Big panini-style sandwiches with the famous bread, jamon, and gruyere or pastrami and provolone were a delicious substitute. Pastries were beautiful, but the plate-sized chocolate chip cookies were too big for my taste. The industrial-size gaugeres were also too big so that the inside choux was pasty with an uncooked taste. Bread is the reason to go.

Best coconut cream pie evar!. Truly delicious cream pie and brioche bread pudding...exquisite, really. So many great looking items to choose from and a little out of the way but worth the trip for visitors. Service left a lot to be desired--aloof and unhelpful at the counter and honestly? If I'm going to clear my table (at your request) then it behooves your staff to at least instruct me *kindly* to step behind the cashier and put my dishes in your service area and say thank you. N'est-ce pas ?

I'm a believer. Yes the line is ridiculous, but it's an afterthought once you sink your teeth into any of the pastries that are made here. There's really not much to be said other than the simple fact that this is one of the best bakeries in existence today. And if you like chocolate croissants, get ready to lose yourself after a few bites of the most incredibly flaky, yet chewy, buttery and creamy croissant you will ever have. I can't wait to go back.
If I could vacation inside. If I could pop a tent and vacation inside, mmmmmm what a vacation it would be.

Worth the wait!. The line up was long but that didn't deter us. Once inside we ordered a few croissants and a coconut tart. The croissant was heavenly and my husband absolutely loved the tart. He was not impressed when he saw the line when we walked up but I had assured him I had heard good things, he later told me it was SO WORTH IT!!
OMG. They have mastered the croissant! You will only find one like this in l'Isle sur la Sorgue. Grab a coffee and sit outside. You will have not one regret.
This place is simply the best bakery ever. I can't say enough good things. Give the place a try and you won't be disappointed!

AMAZING.. A must-stop whenever I am in San Francisco...and I don't usually do breakie! Truth be told, I'll go to Tartine ANY time of day. The bread pudding, yum. The morning buns? Don't be fooled...They look dry, but are DIVINE! Le café est très bon aussi. If only they could get rid of the monster line-ups!

Know what you want when it's time to order.. In Portland there's a brilliant bakery called Ken's, and I thought for a while, that even Tartine wouldn't beat it, but Tartine is divine. The croissants, are rich, light, giant, flaky messes. The Gougeres are eggy, light, rich cheesy bombs. The morning buns are just the same, rich, light, yada yada.
So effing good.

-----11 Jan, 2011-----
Thank god there isn't a Tartine where I live or I'd be so very fat.

My wife and I got here about 30 minutes before they closed and had a slice of pecan pie and a shortbread cookie; both were delicious. The pecan pie featured a buttery and flaky crust, moist filling, and fresh pecans. Outstanding! The shortbread cookie was good, but nothing too special. Decaf was just OK, but it was the end of the night, so you can't complain. My only real complaint is that 30 minutes before closing their selection was slim, as appearently they will not sell slices of certain cakes that late in the evening and had run out of several deserts. That said, it is worth the buzz.

Yummy In My Tummy. I liked the tortes and the brownie was the BEST I've EVER had... and I'm a brownie connoisseur. 

Head ups - you're going to have to wait in line, but it moves pretty fast

Their Croque Monsieur was well, terrible, so skip that. (Not like the real thing at all, tasted more like pizza). Their quiche looked phenomenal though.

A bakery with a good drink list?!!. We made a point to try out this Bakery even though we were staying far away and it was well worth it. We loved the lemon creme tart and the chocolate pots de creme. There was live music and a good crowd enjoying dessert and wine. I wish they were open later because we had to rush dinner to make it there before they closed. A dessert spot should be open at dessert times (8-10pm). But overall, we loved the desserts and the atmosphere and I loved that there was a bar with a good wine and liquor selection. More bakeries should serve wine and cocktails!
Oh so YUMMY!! Everything was delicious.
Luscious pastries and a bread pudding to die for..... Very serious joint. Get the country bread loaf on Wednesday afternoons.
